articles.author: Mads Stoumann
articles.description:
Doing a quick search here on CSS-Tricks shows just how many different ways there are to approach calendars. Some show how CSS Grid can create the layout efficiently. Some attempt to bring actual data into the mix. Some …
Making Calendars With Accessibility and Internationalization in Mind originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Making Calendars With Accessibility and Internationalization in Mind

articles.author: Richard Oliver Bray
articles.description:
You know what it’s like to pick up a new language or framework. Sometimes there’s great documentation to help you find your way through it. But even the best documentation doesn’t cover absolutely everything. And when you work with something …
5 Mistakes I Made When Starting My First React Project originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: 5 Mistakes I Made When Starting My First React Project

articles.author: Mads Stoumann
articles.description:
CSS trigonometry functions are here! Well, they are if you’re using the latest versions of Firefox and Safari, that is. Having this sort of mathematical power in CSS opens up a whole bunch of possibilities. In this tutorial, I thought …
Creating a Clock with the New CSS sin() and cos() Trigonometry Functions originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Creating a Clock with the New CSS sin() and cos() Trigonometry Functions

articles.author: Ganesh Dahal
articles.description:
Fonts are a defining characteristic of the design of any site. That includes WordPress themes, where it’s common for theme developers to integrate a service like Google Fonts into the WordPress Customizer settings for a “classic” PHP-based theme. That hasn’t …
Managing Fonts in WordPress Block Themes originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Managing Fonts in WordPress Block Themes

articles.author: Šime Vidas
articles.description:
I was reading “Creative List Styling” on Google’s web.dev blog and noticed something odd in one of the code examples in the ::marker section of the article. The built-in list markers are bullets, ordinal numbers, and letters. The ::marker pseudo-element …
Everything You Need to Know About the Gap After the List Marker originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Everything You Need to Know About the Gap After the List Marker

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Jan Amann)
articles.description: In this article, Jan Amann, based on an example of a multilingual app that displays street photography images from Unsplash, explores next-intl to implement all internationalization needs in React Server Components.
articles.title: Internationalization In Next.js 13 With React Server Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (William Lyon)
articles.description: In this article, William Lyon explores how to build a full stack GraphQL application that takes advantage of the API Routes feature of Next.js API to combine your GraphQL server and front-end React applications into a single framework.
articles.title: Full Stack GraphQL With Next.js, Neo4j AuraDB And Vercel

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick O’Brien)
articles.description: Perhaps more than any other person in history, Leonardo da Vinci showed the kind of magic that can happen in the overlap between art and science, where much of web development lives. His methods and outlooks are just as applicable to the web today as they were in Renaissance Italy.
articles.title: What Leonardo Da Vinci Can Teach Us About Web Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Instead of telling you once again what the best practice is and adding to your imposter syndrome, let’s concentrate on some practical approaches to user research that we might be able to fit into our existing projects without being left disillusioned.
articles.title: A Pragmatist’s Guide To Lean User Research

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Olufunke Moronfolu)
articles.description: Did you know that creating a complex form can be progressively enhanced using some Vue features like the v-for and the v-model? In this article, Olufunke shares some basic Vue core features that are super useful when building out the complex form in your day-to-day Vue usage.
articles.title: Building Complex Forms In Vue

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Scanlon)
articles.description: In this article, Paul Scanlon shares a super lightweight approach to creating a Donut chart using conic-gradient(). There are no additional libraries to install or maintain, and there’s no heavy JavaScript that needs to be downloaded by the browser in order for them to work.
articles.title: How To Create Dynamic Donut Charts With TailwindCSS And React

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adam Cowley)
articles.description: In this article, Adam Cowley examines the Graph behind GraphQL and demonstrates why Neo4j could be the best fit for your next project.
articles.title: Why You Should Consider Graphs For Your Next GraphQL Project

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Do you sometimes feel that all websites look the same? In this post, we compiled web design showcases that prove differently. They highlight some of the finest web designs, well-crafted experiences, and delightful interactions from across the web. Inspiration is guaranteed.
articles.title: Inspiring Web Design And UX Showcases

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nick Babich & Gleb Kuznetsov)
articles.description: In this article, Nick and Gleb cover the current state of design, answer common questions designers have about AI tools, and share practical tips on how designers can make the most of using AI tools.
articles.title: How AI Technology Will Transform Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lisi Linhart)
articles.description: In this article, Elisabeth Wieser-Linhart explores its potential benefits and drawbacks and shares what considerations and steps were involved in the process of migrating the front-end interface of Storyblok’s headless content management system.
articles.title: Moving From Vue 1 To Vue 2 To Vue 3: A Case Study Of Migrating A Headless CMS System

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s get ready for March with some fresh wallpapers! Designed with love by the community for the community, the wallpaper designs in this collection are available in versions with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: Daydreaming In March (2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mikołaj Dobrucki)
articles.description: In the ever-evolving design tools landscape, it can be difficult to keep up with the latest and greatest. In this article, we’ll take a closer look at Penpot, the first design and prototyping tool that’s fully open-source and based on open web standards, making it an ideal choice for both designers and developers.
articles.title: Meet Penpot, An Open-Source Design Platform Made For Designers And Developers Alike

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sandrina Pereira)
articles.description: Each time we build a field validation from scratch, accessibility doesn’t come out of the box. In this guide, Sandrina breaks down what we need to take into consideration, so that nobody gets stuck on an inaccessible invalid field.
articles.title: A Guide To Accessible Form Validation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Brand new conference on design & UX, for designers and UI engineers who love the web. On design systems, usability, product design and complex UIs. That’s SmashingConf Antwerp, taking place in magical Bourla on October 9–11, 2023.
articles.title: Chocolate, Waffles And Fries: Meet SmashingConf Antwerp 2023 🇧🇪

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Manuel Schröder)
articles.description: Let’s see how to achieve phenomenal web performance and great developer experience with Astro and a headless CMS, resulting in the best possible experience for users, developers and content creators alike.
articles.title: Building Future-Proof High-Performance Websites With Astro Islands And Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani & Arisa Fukuzaki)
articles.description: This article will show you the impact of internationalization, its fundamental logic, how to approach it with Remix, and optionally, how to manage it more conveniently using a headless CMS.
articles.title: Getting Internationalization (i18n) Right With Remix And Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode of the Smashing Podcast, we ask what’s the key to a great keyboard? Is this essential part of our daily toolkit easily overlooked? Vitaly Friedman talks to expert Marcin Wichary to find out.
articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 57 With Marcin Wichary: What’s The Key To A Great Keyboard?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Yuschick)
articles.description: An accessible product can be daunting to build as there’s so much nuance and technical depth to consider. In this article, Daniel Yuschick demonstrates three keys for approaching and developing accessible content without leaving you lost in the weeds.
articles.title: Keys To An Accessibility Mindset

articles.author: Mikael Lassa
articles.description: In Java, method overloading and method overriding both refer to creating different methods that share the same name.  While the two concepts share some similarities, they are distinct notions with markedly different use cases. Having a firm grasp of them is important in building strong foundational Java skills.
articles.title: Method Overloading vs Method Overriding in Java – What's the Difference?

articles.author: Shittu Olumide
articles.description: Mark Twain said that the secret of getting ahead is getting started. Programming can seem daunting for beginners, but the best way to get started is to dive right in and start writing code.  Simple code examples are a great way for beginners to get their feet wet and
articles.title: Python Program Examples – Simple Code Examples for Beginners

articles.author: Ihechikara Vincent Abba
articles.description: The binary search algorithm is a divide and conquer algorithm that you can use to search for and find elements in a sorted array.  The algorithm is fast in searching for elements because it removes half of the array every time the search iteration happens.  So instead of
articles.title: Binary Search in C++ – Algorithm Example

articles.author: Dionysia Lemonaki
articles.description: In this article, you will learn how to use the range() function in Python with the help of code examples along the way. What is the range() Function in Python? range() Function Syntax Breakdown Python's built-in range() function is mainly used when working with for loops – you can use
articles.title: Python range() Function Example

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: It’s possible to use RegEx inside a lambda function in Python. You can apply this to any Python method or function that takes a function as a parameter. Such functions and methods include filter(), map(), any(), sort(), and more. Keep reading as I show you how to use regular expressions
articles.title: Python RegEx Tutorial – How to use RegEx inside lambda Expression

articles.author: Oluseye Jeremiah
articles.description: Generating reports from SQL databases is a common task in many organizations. But the process can be time-consuming and error-prone, especially if it involves manual data extraction, transformation, and formatting.  In this article, we will explore how to use Python to automate the process of generating reports from SQL
articles.title: How to Generate Automated Reports from a SQL Database Using Python

articles.author: Eamonn Cottrell
articles.description: Spreadsheets are the OG resource for visualizing data with charts and graphs...unless you count chalkboards, I suppose.  Spreadsheets are built to churn through tons of data. And by using a few simple built-in tools, you can glean valuable insights from large chunks of data. gif of "OG" graphicWhen dealing
articles.title: Data Visualization in Google Sheets for Beginners

articles.author: Shittu Olumide
articles.description: Creating and manipulating arrays is an essential skill for any Java programmer. Arrays provide a way to store and organize multiple values of the same type, making it easier to work with large sets of data. In this article, we will provide a step-by-step guide on how to create an
articles.title: How to Create an Array in Java – Array Declaration Example

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: The sort() method and the sorted() function let you sort iterable data like lists and tuples in ascending or descending order. They take parameters with which you can modify how they perform the sorting. And one of those parameters could be a function or even a lambda function. In this
articles.title: Lambda Sorted in Python – How to Lambda Sort a List

articles.author: Oluwatobi Sofela
articles.description: CSS Grid gives you the tools to create basic and advanced website layouts in responsive ways that look great on mobile, tablet, and desktop devices. This tutorial discusses everything you need to know to use CSS Grid like a pro. Table of Contents  1.  What Is CSS Grid?
articles.title: CSS Grid Handbook – Complete Guide to Grid Containers and Grid Items
